body:
I don't think anyone has said "no, it should not be marked experimental".
That is a fine idea.  One really nice thing about the solution is that if
you don't need binary-only packages then you will not notice this at all.
If you do need binary-only packages, you will be very grateful that this is
part of 1.7.  This will also make Go more appealing for commercial
products.  The GNU C compiler was going nowhere fast (in the commercial
world) until RMS relented and introduced the LGPL.

On Tue, Apr 26, 2016 at 8:18 AM, Florin Pățan <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> This has been an issue since 1.5 and has been ignored since then (it has
> always been "we will address in release N+1"). Kicking the can down the
> road has proven to not be helpful.
>
> @pborman <https://github.com/pborman> to be a bit mean, that's what they
> do with generics for the last 6 years, no? Not to mention other issues
> (multiple package coverage, etc...) I don't want to go there but this is
> not a technical argument for a good implementation of a solution imho.
>

At least generics work as well today as they did in 1.4.2 and 1.0 :-)  I
can't really say that about binary only package releases.

The reason this is being "rushed" into 1.7 is because it was not done for
1.6 after 1.5 broken the existing recipes, and people are being held back
to 1.4.2.  This is something I have had discussions about with various
members of the Go team since 1.5.  There have been issues filed about it.

It seems you are saying that Russ did not go far enough and those questions
(how to make go get work, how does IntelliJ work with it, what about
vendoring) must be answered before anything goes in.  I disagree, I think
Russ took the appropriate minimal solution for 1.7.  All those other things
can be discussed and addressed once we have more experience.  I don't think
it would be possible to get a good answer for vendoring at this point as
the vendoring we have already has enough questions.  I can see an easy
possible answer to vendoring, but it assumes that binary-only packages are
freely redistributable, but I don't think that will be the case.  You are
correct that that vendoring needs more thought.

So, by all means, let's mark it experimental, let's have more discussions
and debates, but let's *not* let those things from precluding this common
sense minimal solution for 1.7.  Right now it feels that the discussion has
been how to put up roadblocks to getting this minimal solution into 1.7.

    -Paul
